sect1.title: The Cairn Hills
sect1.para: Politically, the Cairn Hills are part of the Shire of Northwood, and have no significance as far as borders and ownership is concerned. Several hundreds border onto the region, but due to the low population found actually within the hills, little effort is made to police the area.

Geographically, the region is more notable. The hills rise up from the plains to the east, and can be seen from most of the trade routes that link the north and the south. The western parts are covered in thick woodland, and the south descends into the tangled darkness of Meam's Wood, which officially has a population of zero, though unofficially is home to various outlaw bands and numerous fell beasts.
The hills are chalk, with an average height of two to three hundred metres. The tallest hills are in the northwest, where the occasional 400m peak can be found.

sect2.title: Folk lore
sect2.para: The Cairn Hills are well renowed in folk lore for being a place of unnatural happenings. To the early tribes, these lands were sacred, and still sometimes host religious ceremonies held by small cults.

sect3.title: The Riders
sect3.para: One of the most common legends about the hills is that of the Riders - warrior horsemen who, it is said, are doomed to ride eternally, never setting foot on land. When the lands were ruled by barbarians, there was a king called Enstig Longhair, who ruled the lands around the Cairn Hills.

Legend has it that he married a woman of the otherlands, a fey beauty who spirited him and his huscarls off to her home to live for eternity. Every now and again, he and his men return to patrol their original kingdom. If they ever set a foot on the earth, then the years they have cheated will catch up with them, and they will die.
The Riders are reported about every 10 years.

sect3.title: The Last Elder
sect3.para: It is generally thought that the Cairn Hills were considered sacred by the Druidic tribes who lived here before the coming of the people of Rorn, and that many secrets of the Elders are buried beneath some of the hills.

The most common story about the Elders is that the last of them was killed here in the final years of the war against the Druids. The Elder was slain above his temple, which was burnt and buried to keep its dark secrets from preying eyes. Many people have looked for it, though none have conclusively found it. Some say that it is beneath Ashek's Tower, whilst others think that it is a different place.
The truth may never be known, especially since the people of the Cairn Hills are not the only ones to claim that the last of the Elders was slain near their home.

sect1.title: Rorn's Vale
sect1.para: Rorn's Vale is a typical hundred town, with a population of about four hundred. The thegn here, Berdun, is an old, somewhat bitter man who now lives alone, the rest of his family having either died or left him. His mood has infected much of the village. The reeve is Jarn Hastikson, also a priest of Ashek.

Jarn is old, mad, and somewhat incoherent, which fits his position as a priest of Ashek perfectly. During his saner moments he can be very perceptive and crafty however. He is a wizard, of quite a bit of power, though has forgotton almost as much as he has learned, His specialities are men, animals and weather.

The most respected member of the community is Jangi, daughter of Jarn, though no-one knows her mother. She turned up thirty years ago in Jarn's house, with Jarn claiming he was her father. She is unmarried. She has black hair, green eyes and very pale skin. When she was 12, she went missing for several days, and when she was found she had tatoos across her chest, left shoulder and back, and wouldn't say what had happened.

sect2.title: People
sect2.para: Rorn's Vale is quite a way off the major trade routes, and needs to be pretty much self supporting wherever possible. It is a focal point for those who live in and around the Cairn Hills.

sect1.title: The Cairns
sect1.para: Spread across the southern hills in a rough east - west line are the cairns. There are about four dozen in all, though legend has it that their true number cannot be accurately counted. There are six major cairns, which each have extensive crypts beneath them. The rest are single caves, or simple mounds containing no more than one or two bodies.

sect3.title: The Round Chamber
sect3.para: A tunnel goes directly into a steep hillside - getting to it can be difficult. There is a large round chamber within, with some smaller chambers off from the main one.

sect3.title: Ecbrit's Cairn
sect3.para: The Ecbrit in question was a recent thegn who had himself buried here along with the other warriors. His tormented ghost is often seen near to the site. It is a simple mound, but has the most extensive tunnel system of any of the cairns.

sect3.title: The White Man
sect3.para: A chalk man with spear is carved into the top of this hill. There is an entrance beneath the man's feet.

sect3.title: Stone Shield Hill
sect3.para: A mound fifteen metres long, six metres wide and some three metres tall. It's sides are ringed with flat, circular stones, and there is a stone archway leading into a narrow chamber at the east end.

sect3.title: Four Barrows
sect3.para: Four barrows aligned facing towards each other.

sect1.title: Ashek's Tower
sect1.para: The strangest feature of the hills is that of Ashek's Tower. It rises 25m above ground level as a steep hill, the top of which opens into a rocky shaft which drops about 50m almost straight down to a small, subterranean lake.

sect1.title: Meam's Wood
sect1.para: To the south of the Cairn Hills, lays an area of thick wood and marsh known as Meam's Wood. It is a place that is avoided by common folk, since the place has a reputation that exceeds that of the Cairns in unpleasentness.

It is believed that Meam sought refuge here after he had been driven out by his father, and that the place picked up on his poisonous, hate filled thoughts and made them real. Most of the stories of strange beasts that dwell here now are just stories, but not all of them. The occasional beast is caught or killed on the edge of the region, but darker things are said to dwell in the deepest parts.

sect2.title: Geography
sect2.para: There is little in the way of a definite border to the north. The Cairn Hills become wooded in their southernmost extremities, and gradually drop down towards the marshes. At some point, the woods thicken enough for the fell beasts to be found hunting, but the exact point changes from year to year.

The marshland is not particularly deep or unpleseant - there are worse marshes to be found. They are however quite extensive, and the addition of the creatures that dwell there is what makes them notable. Most the the marshland is also wooded, though the woods are somewhat lighter than in the dryer parts of Meam's Wood.

sect2.title: Men of the Wood
sect2.para: Despite the hardships to be had living here, for those with disagreements with the Queen's Justice, it can be a better home than elsewhere. It is an accepted fact that anyone who dwells here is beyond the reach of the law, since few are willing to persue far into the place.

Because of this, there are a number of outlaw bands who have made a home here. They survive by hunting, raiding surrounding villages and caravans, or stealing from each other. There is little in the way of cooperation between any of the groups.
